ContentDescription: Explore where, when, why and how people across cultures, communities, times, places and/or other contexts experience visual arts, including artworks created by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples
Elaboration: Using viewpoints to explore and/or develop questions to investigate ideas and understandings about artworks, craft works or designs, such as ‘What do I think is the story in this artwork?’ and ‘What do I recognise in this artwork?’

ContentDescription: Explore where, when, why and how people across cultures, communities, times, places and/or other contexts experience visual arts, including artworks created by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples
Elaboration: Using viewpoints to explore and/or develop questions about an artist and their practice; for example, using protocols such as ‘See, Think, Wonder’ to generate questions such as ‘Who is the artist?’, ‘When and where was this artwork created?’ and ‘What materials and techniques might this artist have used?’

ContentDescription: Explore where, when, why and how people across cultures, communities, times, places and/or other contexts experience visual arts, including artworks created by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples
Elaboration: Investigating a diverse range of artworks made by living Australian artists, for example artworks from a local, regional, state or national collection

ContentDescription: Explore where, when, why and how people across cultures, communities, times, places and/or other contexts experience visual arts, including artworks created by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples
Elaboration: Exploring when, where, how and why Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples use visual arts, crafts and designs to share knowledge about cultures, for example during, but not limited to, celebrations such as National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children's Day, National Aborigines and Islanders Day Observance Committee (NAIDOC) Week and National Reconciliation Week or to acknowledge significant occasions such as National Sorry Day

ContentDescription: Explore where, when, why and how people across cultures, communities, times, places and/or other contexts experience visual arts, including artworks created by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples
Elaboration: Identifying similarities and differences in artworks that represent subject matter or ideas they may be exploring in other learning areas; for example, exploring artworks that represent significant events from different times

ContentDescription: Explore where, when, why and how people across cultures, communities, times, places and/or other contexts experience visual arts, including artworks created by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples
Elaboration: Observing how visual conventions are used in artworks and designs created by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples, for example by exploring colours, symbols and patterns used in artworks, with representatives of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities or through resources that are created or co-created by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples

ContentDescription: Explore ways of using visual conventions, visual arts processes and materials
Elaboration: Using viewpoints to develop thinking routines and to reflect on their arts experiences, for example ‘What was challenging about working in a limited timeframe?’, ‘What was something new that I discovered about the material?’ and ‘What failures led to new discoveries?’

ContentDescription: Explore ways of using visual conventions, visual arts processes and materials
Elaboration: Playing with a range of natural and/or constructed materials to experiment with visual conventions and visual arts processes; for example, creating mud sculptures or using sticks, leaves and playdough to explore texture

ContentDescription: Explore ways of using visual conventions, visual arts processes and materials
Elaboration: Examining artworks and trialling layering as a way of building surfaces, colour, texture and interest; for example, experimenting to create a layered world with pastels, then watercolour, ink and wax, and identifying how each material could be used in a future artwork once the experiment is complete

ContentDescription: Explore ways of using visual conventions, visual arts processes and materials
Elaboration: Exploring visual conventions using a wide range of materials, for example by creating lines using media such as pastels, chalk, paint, ripped paper, textiles and markers, or going on a ‘line hunt’ to identify and photograph the different lines they see around their school environment using a digital camera or creating rubbings

ContentDescription: Use visual conventions, visual arts processes and materials to create artworks that communicate ideas, experiences and observations
Elaboration: Using viewpoints and brainstorming to develop ideas for artworks as they experiment with visual conventions, subject matter and materials, for example ‘What happens if I make the subject fill the page?’, ‘Can I change the meaning of my work by using darker or lighter tones?’, ‘What happens if I combine these ideas?’, ‘How can I adapt this idea?’ and ‘What happens if I remove part of this design?’

ContentDescription: Use visual conventions, visual arts processes and materials to create artworks that communicate ideas, experiences and observations
Elaboration: Using a combination of chaotic/accidental mark-making with more detailed intentional mark-making; for example, using blobs of paint with added outlines and detail, then using imagination and creativity to build on the shapes to see what emerges

ContentDescription: Use visual conventions, visual arts processes and materials to create artworks that communicate ideas, experiences and observations
Elaboration: Creating a relief print through nature-printing or creating collagraphs with a raised textured surface using glue, thread/string and textured paper to print monoprints, cutting these shapes out and making a collage with a recognisable form, such as a face or an animal

ContentDescription: Use visual conventions, visual arts processes and materials to create artworks that communicate ideas, experiences and observations
Elaboration: Using 3D construction (sculpture) methods to represent subject matter or ideas being explored in another learning area; for example, building on their understanding of living things as a starting point to use modelling materials such as potato, clay and found objects to represent the life cycle of an insect

ContentDescription: Use visual conventions, visual arts processes and materials to create artworks that communicate ideas, experiences and observations
Elaboration: Using a combination of digital and physical materials and processes to make artworks, such as using photography or drawing apps for painting and drawing to create a collaged abstract work that represents feelings and emotions; for example, responding to music with colour, line and shape to create an artwork that communicates how the music makes them feel

ContentDescription: Present and share artworks in informal settings
Elaboration: Presenting and describing an artwork they have made to the class, a small group or their teacher and explaining what they like about it

ContentDescription: Present and share artworks in informal settings
Elaboration: Creating and presenting a spontaneous and experimental artwork, such as using unlikely objects for brushes, testing colours and ‘brushstrokes’ using expressive movements, then applying a cardboard ‘window’ across the finished painting

ContentDescription: Present and share artworks in informal settings
Elaboration: Using an everyday object as the starting point, drawing the object, then taking it in turns to match each student’s artwork with the appropriate object, explaining how they arrived at their decision

ContentDescription: Present and share artworks in informal settings
Elaboration: Deciding on an appropriate audience and ways to share their artworks; for example, sharing a work in progress with the class or posting their work on a school learning management system
